Problem:
Consider a complex function \(z(t) = x(t) + iy(t)\), where \(x(t)\) and \(y(t)\) evolve over time governed by a system of coupled linear differential equations. The system is represented by \(\dot{z} = Mz\), where \(M\) is a constant matrix. We examine the influence of the Laplace transformation \( \mathcal{L}(z)(s) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st}z(t) dt \) on causal inference between \(x(t)\) and \(y(t)\).

If \( \mathcal{L}(z)(s) \) is applied to \( z(t) \) initially, and occurred transformation is allowed to evolve under \( \dot{z} = Mz \) without further intervention, will the behavior of \( x(T) \) and \( y(T) \) at a future time \(T\) perfectly match their paths had \( z(t) \) been evolved directly under \( \dot{z} = Mz \)?
Explanation: Applying the Laplace transformation alters the functional form of \(z(t)\) by integrating it over an exponential decay, which modifies \(x(t)\) and \(y(t)\) in a non-trivial manner affecting their evolution under the differential system. The time-domain behavior of \(x(T)\) and \(y(T)\) therefore diverges from the original path.
